1.1.full_content:
The working backwards strategy, also known as backsolving, is one of the most powerful time-saving techniques on the ACT Math section. Instead of solving a problem algebraically from scratch, you test the answer choices to see which one works. This strategy is especially useful when the algebra looks complicated, but answer choice testing makes solving easy.

1. What Is Backsolving?

Backsolving means plugging in the answer choices to solve the problem. Instead of setting up equations and solving for x, you test each choice until you find the one that satisfies the conditions in the problem.

  • Key advantages:
    • Faster than traditional algebra on many problems
    • Less chance of making algebraic mistakes
    • Works great when answer choices are concrete numbers
  • When to Backsolve:
    • The problem asks for a specific value
    • Answer choices are numbers (not expressions)
    • The algebra looks messy or time-consuming

2. The Backsolving Process

Follow these five steps to backsolve efficiently:

Step 1: Strategic Starting

  • On the ACT, answer choices are always listed in ascending order (smallest to largest) or descending order (largest to smallest)
    • Start with B or C (the middle value) - you can often eliminate 2-3 choices with one test
    • If C is too big, you know D and E are also too big
    • If C is too small, you know A and B are also too small

Step 2: Test the Choice

  • Substitute the answer choice into the problem conditions
    • Does it make the equation true?
    • Does it satisfy all the constraints?
    • Does it produce the correct result?

Step 3: If It Works, You're Done!

  • If this answer choice works correctly, bubble it in and move on to the next question

Step 4: Elimination and Adjustment

  • If the answer doesn't work, cross it off
    • Determine if you need a larger or smaller value
    • Cross off any other choices you can eliminate

Step 5: Repeat

  • Pick one of the remaining answer choices and plug it back into the question
    • Continue until you find the correct answer
    • Remember: one of the 5 answer choices must work!

3. Classic Backsolving Problems

Example 1: Basic Backsolving

If √x + 10 − 2√x − 2 = 0, what is the value of x?

A. 2
B. 6
C. 14
D. 18
E. 22

Solution:

  • Start with C (14): √14 + 10 − 2√14 − 2 = √24 − 2√12 ≈ 4.9 − 6.9 ≠ 0 (doesn't work)
  • Try B (6): √6 + 10 − 2√6 − 2 = √16 − 2√4 = 4 − 2(2) = 4 − 4 = 0 ✓

Answer: B

4. When NOT to Backsolve

Backsolving isn't always the best strategy. Avoid it when:

  • Answer choices are algebraic expressions (not numbers)
  • The traditional algebra is very simple
  • Testing answer choices would be more work than solving directly
  • The problem has multiple variables and complex relationships

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Backsolving means using answer choices to solve instead of traditional algebra
  • ✓Always start with choice B or C since answers are ordered by value
  • ✓Use backsolving when answer choices are concrete numbers and algebra looks messy
  • ✓Avoid backsolving when choices are expressions or when algebra is simple
  • ✓Testing one choice can often eliminate 2-3 other choices simultaneously

2.1.full_content:
Understanding angles and lines is fundamental to success on the ACT Math section. These concepts appear in approximately 6-8 questions on every test, making them one of the highest-yield topics to master. Whether dealing with parallel lines, triangles, or polygons, a solid grasp of angle relationships will save you time and boost your score.

1. Intersecting Lines and Angle Relationships

When two lines intersect, they create four angles. Understanding the relationships between these angles is crucial for solving ACT geometry problems quickly.

  • Vertical angles are equal:
    • Opposite angles formed by intersecting lines are always congruent
    • If one angle is 50°, the angle across from it is also 50°
  • Adjacent angles are supplementary:
    • Angles that share a side add up to 180°
    • If you know one angle, you can find all the others
  • All four angles around a point sum to 360°

2. Parallel Lines Cut by a Transversal

When parallel lines are intersected by another line (called a transversal), special angle relationships emerge. The ACT loves testing these relationships because many students find the terminology confusing.

The Simple Rule

  • Instead of memorizing terms like "alternate interior angles" and "corresponding angles," remember this: When two parallel lines are cut by a transversal, you get two sets of identical angles
    • Four angles will be equal to each other (the "small" angles)
    • Four angles will be equal to each other (the "large" angles)
    • Any "small" angle + any "large" angle = 180°

Quick Identification

  • On the ACT, if you see two parallel lines with a third line crossing them:
    • Find any angle that you know
    • All acute angles are equal to each other
    • All obtuse angles are equal to each other
    • Each acute angle + each obtuse angle = 180°

3. Triangle Angle Relationships

The most important rule about triangles: the sum of interior angles in any triangle is always 180°. This rule appears on almost every ACT test.

Special Triangle Types

  • Isosceles triangles have two equal sides and two equal angles
    • The angles opposite the equal sides are equal
    • If two angles are marked equal, the sides opposite them are also equal
  • Equilateral triangles have three equal sides and three 60° angles
  • Right triangles have one 90° angle
    • The other two angles must sum to 90°
    • Common right triangle angle pairs: 30°-60°, 45°-45°

Example 1: Triangle with Parallel Lines

In the figure below, line AB is parallel to line CD. A triangle is formed with angles 34° and 90°. If x° is the alternate interior angle to the third angle of the triangle, what is x?

A. 34
B. 40
C. 48
D. 56
E. 62

Solution:

  • Find the third angle in the triangle: 180° − 34° − 90° = 56°
  • Since x and the third angle are alternate interior angles (and the lines are parallel), they must be equal: x = 56°

Answer: D

4. Interior Angles of Polygons

The ACT frequently tests your ability to find the sum of interior angles in polygons. While you should memorize common polygons, there's one formula that works for all of them:

Sum of Interior Angles = 180°(n − 2)
where n = number of sides

Common Polygons to Memorize

  • Triangle (3 sides): 180°
  • Quadrilateral (4 sides): 360°
    • Includes squares, rectangles, parallelograms, trapezoids
  • Pentagon (5 sides): 540°
  • Hexagon (6 sides): 720°

Example 2: Pentagon with Variable Angles

A pentagon has angles measuring x°, 1.3x°, 1.4x°, 1.2x°, and 1.1x°. What is the value of x?

A. 72
B. 88
C. 90
D. 105
E. 120

Solution:

  • Use the formula: Sum = 180°(5 − 2) = 180°(3) = 540°
  • Set up equation: x° + 1.3x° + 1.4x° + 1.2x° + 1.1x° = 540°
  • Combine like terms: 6x° = 540°, so x = 90

Answer: C

5. ACT Strategy Tips

Here are three powerful strategies to use on angle problems:

Tip 1: Mark Up Your Test

  • When you find one angle, immediately mark any equal angles in the figure
    • Label vertical angles with the same value
    • Mark corresponding angles when you see parallel lines
    • Write supplementary angle values next to each other

Tip 2: Trust the Figure (Usually)

  • All ACT figures are drawn to scale unless they explicitly state "Note: Figure not drawn to scale"
    • You can estimate angles and eliminate obviously wrong answers
    • If an angle looks obtuse, it's probably greater than 90°
    • Use your pencil to compare angle sizes visually

Tip 3: Extend Parallel Lines

  • When parallel lines don't extend all the way across the figure:
    • Use your pencil to extend them through the entire diagram
    • This makes it much easier to identify corresponding and alternate angles
    • Works especially well with parallelograms and trapezoids

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Adjacent angles formed by intersecting lines are supplementary (sum to 180°)
  • ✓When parallel lines are cut by a transversal, you get two sets of identical angles
  • ✓All angles in a triangle always sum to 180°
  • ✓Sum of interior angles = 180°(n − 2) where n is the number of sides
  • ✓Mark up figures as you solve and trust that ACT diagrams are drawn to scale

The number substitution technique, also called plugging in numbers, is a powerful ACT strategy that transforms abstract algebra into simple arithmetic. Instead of manipulating variables and expressions, you substitute actual numbers for variables to test which answer choice works. This technique is especially effective when answer choices contain variables or when the algebra looks overwhelming.

1. What Is Number Substitution?

Number substitution means picking your own numbers to replace variables in the problem. You calculate a target answer using your chosen numbers, then test each answer choice with those same numbers to see which one matches your target.

  • Key advantages:
    • Converts complex algebra into simple arithmetic
    • Reduces chance of algebraic manipulation errors
    • Works excellently when answer choices contain variables
    • Often faster than traditional algebra
  • When to Use Substitution:
    • Answer choices contain variables (like x, n, a + b)
    • The problem says "in terms of" another variable
    • The algebra involves multiple variables or complex expressions
    • You can easily pick numbers that satisfy the problem's conditions

Example 1: Basic Substitution

For all values of x, which of the following is equivalent to (x + 3)(x + 5)?

A. x2 + 15
B. x2 + 8x + 8
C. x2 + 8x + 15
D. 2x + 8
E. x2 + 15x

Solution:

  • Pick x = 2 (simple number, not 0 or 1)
  • Calculate target: (2 + 3)(2 + 5) = (5)(7) = 35
  • Test C: 22 + 8(2) + 15 = 4 + 16 + 15 = 35 ✓

Answer: C

2. The Substitution Process

Follow these four steps to substitute numbers effectively:

Step 1: Choose Smart Numbers

  • Pick numbers that make calculations easy but avoid common traps:
    • ✓ Use simple numbers like 2, 3, 4, 5, 10
    • ✗ Avoid 0 (causes division by zero, special cases)
    • ✗ Avoid 1 (neutral for multiplication, masks patterns)
    • ✗ Avoid -1 (can create confusing results)
    • ✓ If problem involves fractions, pick numbers that simplify easily
    • ✓ If problem involves percent, consider using 100

Step 2: Calculate Your Target

  • Use your chosen numbers to work through the problem
    • Calculate what the answer should be with your numbers
    • This becomes your target value
    • Write it down clearly

Step 3: Test Each Answer Choice

  • Plug your chosen numbers into each answer choice
    • Substitute carefully - one variable at a time
    • Calculate the result for each choice
    • Compare with your target value

Step 4: Verify Your Answer

  • The choice that matches your target is correct
    • If multiple choices match, pick different numbers and test again
    • This rarely happens with well-chosen numbers
